intro: Achillea bocconii, commonly known as the Italian yarrow, is a perennial herb native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves and flat-topped clusters of small, white or pale yellow flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and prefers well-drained, sunny soils. It is often used in landscaping for its ornamental value and has historical uses in traditional medicine. Its common name is derived from the Greek myth of Achilles, who was said to have used the plant to treat wounds.
